data.name: StringFormatAnalyzerTitle
data.value: Use TextTools.FormatString() instead of string.Format()

data.name: StringFormatAnalyzerMessageFormat
data.value: Caller uses string.Format() instead of TextTools.FormatString()

data.name: StringFormatAnalyzerDescription
data.value: TextTools.FormatString() uses the error handler to handle unknown formatting errors and returns the unformatted string if such errors happen, but string.Format() immediately throws.

data.name: ConsoleWrapperUsageAnalyzerTitle
data.value: Use ConsoleWrapper instead of Console

data.name: ConsoleWrapperUsageAnalyzerMessageFormat
data.value: Caller uses Console instead of ConsoleWrapper

data.name: ConsoleWrapperUsageAnalyzerDescription
data.value: ConsoleWrapper makes sure that your console is not a dumb console. This class is a wrapper for the Console class so that it works cross-platform, while Console contains some platform-dependent APIs.

data.name: ConsoleTitleUsageAnalyzerTitle
data.value: Use SetTitle() instead of Console.Title

data.name: ConsoleTitleUsageAnalyzerMessageFormat
data.value: Caller uses Console.Title instead of SetTitle()

data.name: ConsoleTitleUsageAnalyzerDescription
data.value: SetTitle() uses the VT sequence to set the title, while Console.Title works in certain conditions.

data.name: ConsoleForeColorUsageAnalyzerTitle
data.value: Use SetConsoleColor(Color) instead of Console.ForegroundColor

data.name: ConsoleForeColorUsageAnalyzerMessageFormat
data.value: Caller uses Console.ForegroundColor instead of SetConsoleColor(Color)

data.name: ConsoleForeColorUsageAnalyzerDescription
data.value: SetConsoleColor(Color) not only brings better color support provided by the appropriate VT sequences, but it can also use true color. Console.ForegroundColor only handles 16 colors.

data.name: ConsoleBackColorUsageAnalyzerTitle
data.value: Use SetConsoleColor(Color, true) instead of Console.BackgroundColor

data.name: ConsoleBackColorUsageAnalyzerMessageFormat
data.value: Caller uses Console.BackgroundColor instead of SetConsoleColor(Color, true)

data.name: ConsoleBackColorUsageAnalyzerDescription
data.value: SetConsoleColor(Color, true) not only brings better color support provided by the appropriate VT sequences, but it can also use true color. Console.BackgroundColor only handles 16 colors.

data.name: ConsoleReadLineUsageAnalyzerTitle
data.value: Use ReadLine() instead of Console.ReadLine

data.name: ConsoleReadLineUsageAnalyzerMessageFormat
data.value: Caller uses Console.ReadLine instead of ReadLine()

data.name: ConsoleReadLineUsageAnalyzerDescription
data.value: ReadLine() provided by the input helper from Nitrocid allows you to seamlessly read a user input with settings provided by Terminaux.

data.name: ConsoleWriteUsageAnalyzerTitle
data.value: Use TWC.Write() instead of Console.Write

data.name: ConsoleWriteUsageAnalyzerMessageFormat
data.value: Caller uses Console.Write instead of TWC.Write()

data.name: ConsoleWriteUsageAnalyzerDescription
data.value: TextWriterColor.Write() contains workarounds for VT sequences needed for Linux hosts to properly report the correct position post-write. Its overloads also allow you to specify the color and the line writing.

data.name: ConsoleWriteLineUsageAnalyzerTitle
data.value: Use TWC.Write() instead of Console.WriteLine

data.name: ConsoleWriteLineUsageAnalyzerMessageFormat
data.value: Caller uses Console.WriteLine instead of TWC.Write()

data.name: ConsoleWriteLineUsageAnalyzerDescription
data.value: TextWriterColor.Write() contains workarounds for VT sequences needed for Linux hosts to properly report the correct position post-write. Its overloads also allow you to specify the color and the line writing.

data.name: ConsoleResetColorUsageAnalyzerTitle
data.value: Use ConsoleExtensions.ResetColors() instead of Console.ResetColor

data.name: ConsoleResetColorUsageAnalyzerMessageFormat
data.value: Caller uses Console.ResetColor instead of ConsoleExtensions.ResetColors()

data.name: ConsoleResetColorUsageAnalyzerDescription
data.value: ConsoleExtensions.ResetColors() contains VT sequences that help reset colors in a portable way.

data.name: DirectoryGetFileSystemEntriesUsageAnalyzerTitle
data.value: Use Listing.CreateList() instead of Directory.GetFileSystemEntries

data.name: DirectoryGetFileSystemEntriesUsageAnalyzerMessageFormat
data.value: Caller uses Directory.GetFileSystemEntries instead of Listing.CreateList()

data.name: DirectoryGetFileSystemEntriesUsageAnalyzerDescription
data.value: Listing.CreateList() returns a list of FileSystemEntry instances that provides you information about a file, as well as a wrapper to the FileSystemInfo instance for that file.

data.name: DirectoryGetFileSystemEntriesAltUsageAnalyzerTitle
data.value: Use Listing.GetFileSystemEntries() instead of Directory.GetFileSystemEntries

data.name: DirectoryGetFileSystemEntriesAltUsageAnalyzerMessageFormat
data.value: Caller uses Directory.GetFileSystemEntries instead of Listing.GetFileSystemEntries()

data.name: DirectoryGetFileSystemEntriesAltUsageAnalyzerDescription
data.value: Alternatively, Listing.GetFileSystemEntries() returns a list of paths to files or folders with better support for patterns. You can also use GetFilesystemEntriesRegex() for regular expression support.
